displayTitle: Are you ready to open up research data?
title: Are you ready to open up research data?

body:
The sharing of scientific research has long been an establish process dating back to the 1660s with the establishment of the Royal Society in England. The publication of journal papers allowed scientists to lay claim to their discoveries while sharing findings with others. 

Centuries later, our ability to share outputs now reaches far beyond just the publication, into the data collected as part of the research process. 

This module looks at:

  • What is research data and why make it open?
  • Where does research data fit?
  • The benefits of opening research data
  • The support for open research data
title: Why open research data?

body:
Research data is defined as material commonly retained by and accepted in the scientific community as necessary to validate research findings. 

It is important to think carefully about this definition and not simply get caught up in publishing all research data; a practice that might lead to confusion. The publication of research data requires careful curation, much like a scientific publication. While the publication should be a careful and concise record of the findings, the data should match this concise record and enable others to combine the research method with the data to validate the findings. 

Although not all material will be digital in existence, for the purposes of this module we are going to look solely at data that does exist in digital form.
title: What is research data?

body: With the main purpose of opening research data being to validate research findings it is important to think carefully about where research data fits in the scholarly publication process. There are many aspects of the process, especially when involving digital tools.
title: Where does research data fit?

_items.title: Scholarly publication
_items.body:
Any published research data should be carefully linked to the research findings. 

Putting together a research publication takes time and you should consider at each stage if there is any additional material required to enable the validation of the research.

_items.title: Research process
_items.body:
Although the research methodology should be outlined clearly in the scholarly publication, the concise nature of the publication does not always allow for the full expression of the process.

Services such as MyExperiment provide a collaborative environment where scientists can safely publish their workflows and in silico experiments. This enables others to view and follow the research process more clearly.

_items.title: Open data
_items.body:
With the process outlined, it is important to try and give access to the relevant data to others. 

If the research has sourced open data then this should be linked to and any specifics over access outlined. If the source data is not open then it will be necessary to carefully check your rights to publish the data for others to use it. 

If you have created the data yourself then you, or your institution, own the data. This means you are free to chose how to publish the data.

It is recommended that data you own is published under an open licence which required attribution. This way much like citation, you can see who is building upon your data.

_items.title: Open source
_items.body:
Alongside the research data you may used or created tools to process the data. Alternatively you might have used algorithms or processes within tools such as matlab. 

It is important to consider how to share these tools as openly as possible as they may be a necessary and indeed core part of the material required to verify your research results.

body: Other than making research verifiable there are a number of other benefits to be gained from opening up research data.
displayTitle: The benefits of opening up research data
title: The benefits of opening up research data

_items.title: Enable reuse
_items.body:
Another key aspect in scientific research is the ability to build upon the research of others, be it in the same domain or a different one. 

The expression 'standing on the shoulders of giants' is commonly used within science to express the desire to 'discover truth by building on previous discoveries'. 

All researchers build on the research of others, so having data that can be used or bought up to date can save a lot of time vs re-collecting from scratch.

_items.title: Increase citation
_items.body:
Citation is a key indicator of impact in science and open practices have been shown to increase citation. 

Studies have found that citation advantage can be gained through a combination of:

  • Open access publication
  • Open source code
  • Open research data

_items.title: Generate impact
_items.body:
'The initial investment is scientific, but the ultimate return is economic and social'

John Wood, currently the Co-Chair of the global Research Data Alliance (RDA), said that people should ‘plan the harvest’ for the economic benefits that the significant public investments in data, research and technical infrastructure are bringing.

Science is not just the study of the world, but also how it can be improved. The benefits of being able to bring the worlds data together as a new scientific resource are not yet being realised due to practices which limit the release of data and then don't preserve it beyond a few years at best.

body: The importance of sharing research data has meant that many parties have now put in place policies and mandates that enforce the publication of research data.
displayTitle: The support for open research data
title: The support for open research data

_items.title: Funder mandates
_items.body:
Many research funders now require at least a statement in each publication on how and on what terms any underlying data can be accessed by third parties.

The Digital Curation Center (DCC) provides a great summary of funders policy's including the requirements for long term curation and monitoring.

_items.title: Institutional policies
_items.body:
Publishing research data can help increase the reputation of not just the researcher but also the research institution. 

Many institutions have now adopted a research data management policy which is designed to support the publication of research data as a part of normal process. 

Read more about the research data management policies of:

  • University of Oxford
  • University of Edinburgh

_items.title: Journals and publishers
_items.body:
Many of the biggest journals and publishers now have data sharing requirements that must be met. You can read more about some of these here:

  • Science’s Data Deposition Policy. Scroll down to the “Data and Materials Availability after Publication” section
  • SpringerNature’s Data Sharing Policies. Journal example: Nature’s policy on Availability of data, materials, and methods
  • Wiley’s Data Sharing Service
  • American Geophysical Union’s Publication Data Policy
  • Sage’s Replication policy

body:
Enriching data is a general term that refers to processes used to enhance, refine or otherwise improve or add value to raw data. This module explores some of the many techniques that are commonly applied to raw data and demonstrates how very little data can lead to immense insight through enriching.

This module explores:

  • Derivation and feature extraction
  • Combining datasets
  • Enriching geographic data
  • Enriching qualitative data
title: How to enrich data

body: Before you think about combining data sources or using external sources, often data can be enriched though a process of derivation or feature extraction. This results in additional columns (or features) being added to your data which are based upon the existing data only.
title: Derivation and feature extraction

_items.title: Derived data
_items.body:
A derived data element is a data element derived from other data elements using a mathematical, logical, or other type of transformation, e.g. arithmetic formula, composition, aggregation. 

For example your source data might contain a series of columns of monthly expenditure. A sum total could be made over all months to add another column. This column is thus derived from the others.

_items.title: Feature extraction
_items.body:
Feature extraction is very similar to derived data however does not necessary have to involve a function.

For example the city could be extracted from a list of unstructured address data, making the city a distinct feature of the dataset.

Likewise the colour of the centre pixel of an image could be extracted without the use of a mathmatical function. 

You can find a short tutorial on feature extraction in excel here.

body:
Not all data comes in the form of structured tables or accurately located geographic data. Often it can be the qualitative data that can be hardest to analyse and work with. Enrichment and feature extraction can be used to help bring structure to the data and reveal insight. 

Entity recognition tools provide one such technique that can help analyse and enrich qualitative data. Essentially entity recognition seeks to locate and classify named entities in text into pre-defined categories such as the names of persons, organisations, locations, expressions of times, quantities, monetary values, percentages, etc.

The Calais (now known just as Intelligent Tagging) service from Thomson Reuters is one such example of an entity recognition engine. More than just entity recognition, the Calais service links those entities to data records that exist within the Thomson Reuters permID database of entities and financial records. Why not try it for yourself at https://permid.org/onecalaisViewer. A good example to try is the top 5 or so paragraphs from any political news article. 

More widely such entity recognition is used by services such as TheyWorkForYou in order to track the activities of politicians and provide this in a easy way to the public.
title: Enriching qualitative data

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [All rights reserved]

body:
Here we are not referring to adding additional data onto the end of an existing dataset (a process known as consolidation) but rather the process of adding to the existing data. 

If you are using a spreadsheet, the result of combining two datasets with 10 columns each will be one dataset with 19 columns. Combining data can only be done in this way if there is a column in each dataset with a shared value. This column becomes the key upon which the combine can be performed. 

For example. Take a dataset of roads and the numbers of cars during each hour of the day. Each hour period is a column and each road is a row. If there were many sources of the data, e.g. sources with different hours in all individually collected, then you could key on the road name and combine all the data into a single dataset. 

Find out how to combine two datasets in Excel or in Open Refine.
title: Combining datasets

body:
Much like combining data, where you can combine two datasets based upon a common feature (e.g. road name) you can do the same with geographic data.

One big difference however is that you can combine geographic data based upon location and whether a location is inside the boundary of another. This process is known as a spatial merge. 

A spatial join can be useful when looking at features of different buildings or services and mapping them on to jurisdiction region to see if any patterns emerge. For example you could use this to see if schools in different council controlled areas perform significantly differently. 

You can find out more about enriching and joining map data using the excellent guides provided by CartoDB.
title: Enriching geographic data

body:
Currently in many data structures the idea of a key - value pair exists, e.g. For data about me:

KeyValue
NameJohn Smith
Age (Years)22
Height (inches)69
Shoe size (UK)8

RDF takes the key+value idea an adds the notion that we need a third item, known as the subject. In this case the subject is me, e.g.

SubjectPredicate / KeyObject / Value
#JohnNameJohn Smith
#JohnAge (Years)22
#JohnHeight (inches)69
#JohnShoe size (UK)8

Note that in the actual RDF standard the key is referred to as a predicate and the value referred to as the object. Thus the three items are known as the subject, predicate and object.
title: Introducing RDF

body: The guides below look at how data in existing tabular, hierarchical and network structures can be translated into RDF triples.
title: Translating existing data to RDF

_items.title: Tabular data
_items.body:
Tabular data should contain 1 row per subject. Then each row should be related to a column heading; just like a key value pair. 

When translating to triples the only challenge is to add an subject to the existing key/value pair. In this example we have looked to the row numbers. Remember that the subject MUST be unique and not replicated elsewhere.

Our triple in this example is:

SubjectPredicateObject
#3Last nameMcCartney

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

_items.title: Hierarchical data
_items.body:
In hierarchical data, the relationships mostly exists and that is should be fairly strait forward to identify the triples. 

The main challenge is to define the relationship and ensure that the subject->predicate->object is in the right direction. 

In the case here we have:

SubjectPredicateObject
#WilliamhasChild#George
#WilliamhasChild#Charlotte
#KatehasChild#George
#KatehasChild#Charlotte

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

_items.title: Network data
_items.body:
Network data, like hierarchical data, already has connections objects and connections between them. The difference between network and hierarchical data is that the same relationship can exists in multiple directions (so a subject can also be an object) and you can end up going around in circles.

From the table below see if you can work out which person is which?

#Person1hasFriend#Person2
#Person1hasFriend#Person3
#Person1hasFriend#Person4
#Person2hasFriend#Person1
#Person2hasFriend#Person3
#Person3hasFriend#Person1

body:
The Resource Description Framework (RDF) proposes simple framework for representing all types of data, regardless of structure. Using the notion of a triple, RDF maps all data structures into a referenceable network data structure. All current structures can be easily translated into RDF providing that it is clear what the subject is to be translated. 

This module has looked at the key aspects of the subject, predicate and object triple. Why not explore how RDF relates to Linked Data and how the predicate can be used to define standards for working intelligently with data from many providers.
title: Summary

In the 5-stars of linked open data, the fourth star states "If you use identifiers for things, make them web based so that people can point at your stuff". In this module we look at how the Resource Description Framework (RDF) also recommends the use of web based identifiers and the caveats of doing so.

This module is structured as follows:

  • The connection between linked open data and RDF
  • What are 4-star identifiers?
  • Designing web based identifiers
  • Implementing services using RDF and linked open data

body:
In the 5-stars of linked open data, the 4th star states "If you use identifiers for things, make them web based so point can point at your stuff".

A good design template for identifiers can also assist with building a web of linked open data. Using RDF is not essential to the web of linked open data however the inverse is not true; RDF and linked open data are intrinsically connected through their use of identifiers.

The most important aspect is to use web based identifiers (IRIs) to identify resources which people and machines can look up to find out what they are.
title: Summary

body:
In the 5-stars of linked open data (shown here) outline steps to publish linked open data. Of particular interest is the 4th star. The 4th star states "If you use identifiers for things, make them web based so people can point at your stuff".

Take for example a company. The unique identifier for a company is usually the company number (e.g. 08030289). To find the company from this number, you would have to type it into a search engine and hope. By contrast, you can follow a web-based identifier for the same company directly from any Web browser, e.g.
https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/08030289.

In the triple structure of the RDF, the company number might be the identifier of the subject which is then described in RDF, e.g. 

SubjectPredicateObject
#08030289hasNameOPEN DATA INSTITUTE

Making the subject a Web based identifier is a logical step to allow users to discover more about the company and even the data itself (see REST/API module).
displayTitle: The connection between linked open data and RDF
title: The connection between linked open data and RDF

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]

body: 4-star compatible identifiers should strive to meet a number of objectives. Meeting all of these will make it easy to achieve full 5-star linked open data.
title: What are 4-star compatible identifiers?

_items.title: 1. Start with http....
_items.body:
Make any identifiers for things (subjects and objects in RDF) http identifiers.

This means that people can easily resolve them on the Web to find out more about them. 

See the next section on how to design good identifiers.

_items.title: 2. Make them resolve
_items.body:
Each http identifier should resolve and offer the user a representation of the thing or the thing itself (see 3.5).

404 (not found) errors and other Web errors should be avoided where possible to keep the identifier available in the long term.

_items.title: 3. Return the thing (if possible)
_items.body:
If the user does not otherwise specify, then by default the thing being identified should be returned. 

For example; if the identifier is for a digital photograph then the identifier should resolve to the original digital photograph, not a Web page about the photograph (see next).

_items.title: 4. Return a human readable version
_items.body:
If it is not possible to return the original and the user requests a human readable Web page (which is what all Web browsers do) then this should be returned to the user. 

Did you know that when a Web browser requests an http page the request looks like the following:

GET http://bbc.co.uk/news HTTP/1.1
Accept: text/html

It is the Accept that tells the provider that the user would like a Web page (text/html type).

_items.title: 5. Return a machine readable version
_items.body:
If the user is a machine then it might request a different representation of the thing being identified, e.g. it might ask for a CSV (tabular) representation. 

GET http://bbc.co.uk/news HTTP/1.1
Accept: text/csv

If possible the provider should be able to provide a number of different representations of the data, perhaps include one or two that are compatible with the RDF specification.

body: Follow the guide above to help you design good Web based identifiers. A Web based identifier is made up of 5 main parts each of which is explored below:
title: Designing web based identifiers

_items.title: {scheme}
_items.body: The scheme in the majority of cases will be http or https (secure). This tells us that the thing being identified can be retrieved via the http protocol.

_items.title: {authority}
_items.body:
The top level domain that is the authority for managing this request.

e.g. companieshouse.gov.uk

It many cases the authority might be the controller for the thing being identified.

In all cases the authority gives the requester an instant indication or the level of trust they might have in the linked item.

_items.title: {path}
_items.body:
There might be many paths (separated by "/") that allow the authority to better separate the management and access to identifiers. 

For example there might be a projects path which is publicly accessible and a people path which is restricted. 

Another example path with authority might be:

http://bbc.co.uk/news/politics/

_items.title: {identifier}
_items.body:
The final part of the path is the identifier for the thing itself. This might already exist elsewhere and commonly might just simply need to be added to the end of the rest of the Web based identifier.

For example if a company has a company number 08030289 then a Web based identifier for this company might be https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/08030289 

Note in this example that the authority has beta in it which suggests that this identifier is unstable and might not be trustworthy in the long term.

_items.title: {fragment}
_items.body:
The fragment follows a # and can be used to enable a user to instantly reference a single part or attribute of the thing being identified.

For example given our company 

https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/
08030289#name

could refer just to the name, or for an image

http://images.org/image/123#width. 

It is worth noting that on the web it is the job of the client to de-reference fragments, the provider should ignore anything after a # in a web identifier.

body:
Once you have designed the identifiers for your resources, these can be used as the subject and object parts of data representations that conform to the Resource Description Framework. Allowing a user to then negotiate for all different representations of resources will allow flexible discovery and use.

Think of using RDF and identifiers as the same as creating human readable Web pages. Web pages help humans, RDF can help machines. Web pages are the equivalent of documents. Humans like editing documents in packages like Microsoft Word or Google Docs, this means that content needs to be available in these formats to allow editing. The same is true for data. If RDF is a discovery mechanism for machines then other data formats like Excel will be required to work with these resources. Neither Web pages, not RDF can replace these other formats. 

Not yet anyway...

To do this each identifier should resolve and provide a human readable and machine readable version. The formats used should be suitable for the data and don't have to be of any particular type.

body:
An Application Programme Interface (API) is best described as a "promise" by one system to constantly and consistently provide a service to another that allows to the two to interact. 

One simple way of thinking of this is to think of spoken languages as an API. Each language has words and grammatical structures that form sentences through which information can be exchanged between people. However not everyone speaks the same language. To solve this problem sometimes you have to learn the new language or use a third party to translate.

Exactly the same is true of machine APIs, except there are many more APIs than languages so applying some standard design principals helps everyone understand the API. This is much like having many dialects of a single spoken languages. In this module we investigate the REST 'dialect' for API design.
title: What is an API?

body: REpresentational State Transfer (REST) is an API designed specifically for the web. It has a specific set of guidelines and rules that control if something is a RESTful API.
title: What is a REST API?

_items.title: Uses web identifiers to address resources
_items.body:
In a REST API all interaction is done directly with resource web based identifiers (URI/IRIs).

Like in linked open data, the IRIs represent the resource itself, not a particular format or representation of the resource (e.g. html).

_items.title: Takes advantage of the web architecture
_items.body:
The web is built using a client-server architecture. For example, to browse the web you do not need to be at the terminal of the computer that holds the files you need.

The web is also stateless, meaning that the server will not maintain information or status of a client between requests. This is the main aspect which helps the web scale.  

The same should be true of a RESTful API.

_items.title: Uses the HTTP protocol as the language
_items.body:
The main language in a REST API is HTTP. The HTTP specification outlines a series of verbs that define how clients can interact with a server and the resources it holds. Verbs allow the client to retrieve (GET), update (POST), overwrite (PUT) and delete (DELETE) resources. 

A REST API that supports all these features is also known as a CRUD (Create, Retrieve, Update, Delete) API.

body:
The module RDF and linked open data outlined how web identifiers (IRI) are important to allow people to click on identifiers to find out what they are. This module also outlined how clicking on the IRI should provide both humans and machines an appropriate representation of the resource.

This is best done through the implementation of a REST API for your resources. A REST API can accommodate both the needs of humans and machines as well as providing service providers a potential new way to manage, organise and expose appropriate data to the appropriate people.
displayTitle: REST APIs and linked open data
title: REST APIs and linked open data

body:
This section introduces the practical application of a RESTful API using the core http verbs. In all cases the interaction is going to be performed with the IRI that represented The Open Data Institute (ODI) as listed in Open Corporates: 

https://opencorporates.com/companies/gb/08030289
title: REST in practice

_items.title: Retrieve (GET)
_items.body:
The simplest operation we can perform is a retrieve. In the HTTP (or CRUD) specification this is referred to as a GET operation as it uses the GET HTTP verb.

The following is what actually happens under the hood when your web browser requests the resource identified by the ODI URI in Open Corporates.

GET /companies/gb/08030289 HTTP/1.1
HOST: opencorporates.com
ACCEPT: text/html

In this GET request it is requesting a specific resource (using the HTTP/1.1 protocol) from opencorproates.com and your browser wants a text/html human readable version it can render. 

For a machine to get a machine readable version the request changes very slightly:

GET /companies/gb/08030289 HTTP/1.1
HOST: opencorporates.com
ACCEPT: application/json

The request is simply asking for a different representation that is supported by the Open Corporates API specification. Currently the JSON format (application/json) is the most common with REST APIs.

_items.title: Create of overwrite (PUT)
_items.body:
PUT /companies/gb/08030289 HTTP/1.1
HOST: opencorporates.com
CONTENT-TYPE: application/json

The PUT HTTP is used to create or completely overwrite a resource at a given IRI. Rather than the server sending back a response the client should provide a representation of the resource to the server and specify which one with a CONTENT-TYPE header. 

It is important to note that in this PUT request the client has specified the whole of the IRI in the request and the server cannot modify it.

_items.title: Create or update (POST)
_items.body:
POST /companies/gb/ HTTP/1.1
HOST: opencorporates.com
CONTENT-TYPE: application/json

Conversely to PUT, if the IRI is being set by the server then a POST should be used to add something to a collection. 

In the case of the request above this would create a new company entry in the gb part of the companies database of open corporates. The server should then respond with the IRI of the new company resource or appropriate error message.

_items.title: Other operations
_items.body:
There are a series of other useful HTTP verbs that can be used directly on an IRI including:

HEAD: Identical to GET but the data or documents is not returned by the server, just a description of the requested content (known as headers). These headers include metadata such as last-modified which is used for checking if a resource has changed since the user (browser) last requested it. 

DELETE: Delete the resource and all representations. Any further GET/HEAD requests should result in a "410 Gone" response from the server.

OPTIONS: See which HTTP verbs the server supports on a given IRI.

PATCH: Partially update a resource (not widely supported).

body: Follow the steps below to design a REST API for your resources and data.
title: Designing a REST API

_items.title: Step 1 - Design core identifier structure
_items.body:
Follow the template above to design and document your web sites structure for where your resources are going to be. This step has several stages:

1. Pick the scheme: http (insecure) or https (secure) - If you are going to support updating of resources you should use https.

2. Pick the authority -  You might have already decided that the website base address you have is the right one.

3. Organise your resources into paths - Pick paths (normally these correspond to database tables or resource types as a way to organise your data. e.g. /companies /students /news /events /transactions /projects /contracts etc etc

4. Decide on identifier patterns - Follow an identifier scheme you already and remember what happens if you allow creation.

_items.title: Step 2 - Document this structure
_items.body:
The next step is to document your path structure. Usually providers documentation will mirror the design pattern shown above, informing people about the available endpoints. 

e.g. 

List all companies
/companies 

Individual records
/companies/{company-number}
/students/:student-number

Dependant on the documentation standard either "{}" or ":" will be used to denote properties that need to be replaced with the identifier before interaction can happen. 

For some examples see the OpenCorporates API and the ODI data API.

_items.title: Step 3 - Choose HTTP verbs to support
_items.body:
The majority of REST APIs are only for the purposes of retrieving (GET) resources however it might be advantageous to also support the ability to add to the data via the API.

The majority of systems need a way to create resources, sometimes only have a single system can be a good thing to control identifiers.

_items.title: Step 4 - Decide on formats/representations
_items.body:
Having designed the API, it is now time to decide which representations/formats (e.g. html, son, xml etc) will be supported.

There is no ideal answer here as different applications suit different representations, structures and formats for data. The minimum requirement should be to make available at least one human and one machine readable representation of each resource.

_items.title: Step 5 - Add support for queries on lists
_items.body:
The optional step could enable you to take advantage of query parameters added to list endpoints (IRIs without the identifier on the end) to customise the search for a user. 

For example a GET request to the following location could return all companies with a status "inactive" from open corporates. 

GET /companies/gb?Status=Inactive HTTP/1.1

Schemas play a key role in enabling the wide, automated re-use of data. This module looks at the role of and importance of schemas in assisting reusability and quality of data.

In this module we explore:

  • What is a schema?
  • Why do schemas matter?
  • Schemas in practice
  • Choosing or designing schemas
title: Choosing and designing schemas

body: The choice (or design) of schema for dataset is a major factor in how useful your data will be to others, both humans and machines. Using existing and widely adopted schemas both helps others use your data and ensures that you can use data from others.
title: Choosing and designing schemas

_items.title: Using an existing schema
_items.body:
The best choice when structuring a dataset is an existing standard schema. Using a standard schema ensures data can be instantly combined with that of other publishers. 

Many data controllers already have a well defined set of supported schema and using them could be as simple as simply renaming some column titles.

In other cases it might be necessary to change the values in data to conform to the schema, e.g. ensuring that units of measurement and date formats match the requirement of the schema.

_items.title: Creating a new schema
_items.body:
No common schema for the dataset you are publishing?

Before creating a new one, why not find out whether there is already some consensus among an existing community of users somewhere (for this, use your favourite search engine).

You might need to contribute a new schema but there may be an opportunity to get the community to help.

body:
A schema is a blueprint for data that defines a set of integrity constraints and rules relating to the structure and contents of a data resource. 

The schema will define a number of key things:
title: What is a schema?

_items.title: Column/Key titles in the data
_items.body:
Defining a consistent set of column titles (or keys) for a data set is essential to ensure that datasets of the same type can be merged and analysed easily. 

Often column titles will change or be abbreviated to save time however this causes a lot of problems when analysing data over long periods of time. 

Adding column titles is less of a problem but has to be taken into account when analysing data.

_items.title: Value types
_items.body:
With the column title/keys defined it is important to define the valid data type for the values, e.g. number, text, date, co-ordinate etc. 

This will help with a simple datatype validation.

_items.title: Value contrainsts
_items.body:
With the value type defined, valid constraints such as being required, need to be unique, being in a certain unit (e.g. Gallons (UK)) or be within a certain range should be defined. 

For example a column might be entitled "Cost (£m)"; thus any values should be numbers (without commas).

Setting a valid range also help avoid and explain any errors in the data. For example setting a range of 0.001-100 on the "Cost (£m)" (if it is known that cost cannot exceed £100m).

Range validation stops people accidentally misreading the column title/units and entering 100000000 instead of 100 for £100m.

There are many schemas already in existence and schema.org has a large community of contributors who are adding to the knowledge base regularly. 

This module has also explored how linked open data can also be implemented in a tabular data structure, however this doesn't mean it is always a good idea.

The reason RDF exists is to propose a single simple structure for all data. If you choose to expose your data in RDF (as well as other representations) then all systems that can import and use RDF can instantly use your data without needing to transform it prior to use.

body:
The first rule of writing schemas in RDF is don’t. Find one that already exists that does the job you need. Sites like schema.org can help and there are a set of community defined and supported schemas out there that you can use. 

Some of the most popular are outlined below but if you really need to create a schema then the w3c primer guide can help but is complex.
title: Choosing and designing schemas

_items.title: FOAF
_items.body:
FOAF (Friend Of A Friend) is a schema blueprint for  describing persons, their activities and their relations to other people and objects. Anyone can use FOAF to describe themselves. FOAF allows groups of people to describe social networks without the need for a centralised database. 

FOAF contains definitions for properties including:

  • name
  • mbox
  • knows
  • homepage

Read more on wikipedia

_items.title: Dublin Core
_items.body:
The Dublin Core Schema is a small set of terms that can be used to describe web resources (video, images, web pages, etc.), as well as physical resources such as books or CDs, and objects like artworks.

Some of the core terms include:

  • Title
  • Creator
  • Description
  • Publisher
  • Source
  • Rights

Read more on wikipedia.

_items.title: SKOS
_items.body: Simple Knowledge Organization System (SKOS) is a designed for representation of thesauri, classification schemes, taxonomies, subject-heading systems, or any other type of structured controlled vocabulary.

_items.title: Schema.org
_items.body:
Schema.org is an initiative designed to “create and support a common set of schemas for structured data markup on web pages.” 

Schema.org propose a method for using the schema.org vocabulary in a number of data formats of all structures. This also includes recommendations on how use on website can be recognized by search engines and users to make the web more machine readable (see Semantic Web module).

Read more on wikipedia.

body:
Applying schemas to data in RDF is likely to make some triples long and hard to read. As a solution to this many data formats allow for the use of PREFIXs. A prefix is simply a substitute for the beginning of the URI so we don’t have to keep typing/reading it e.g.

PREFIX myorg: http://mycompany.org/

This block contains full example. Note that all of the data (bar own own website my org) is genuine and you can easily follow the links to find out more data. dbpedia is a data API for wikipedia that exposes RDF data and has its own schema as used above. There is also use of the owl:sameAs property which allows the use of many identifiers for the exact same thing.
title: Applying schemas to RDF

In module X we look at how all data structures could be mapped to RDF.

However you can also apply the idea of linked data schemas to data without necessarily using RDF.

For example in a tabular data structure the column headings as well as all identifiers could become http IRIs without changing the data format/representation. The example here looks at how you could apply this to a tabular dataset using the data from the previous example. 

Now everything that can potentially be an IRI is, the subject, predicate and object. Note how we have also added columns to define the type of the resource, in this case the Beetles are all people (foaf:person).

This series of modules have now covered the complete set of theory and principals to deliver the web of linked open data. 

So lets summarise:
displayTitle: Completing the linked open data stack (with or without RDF)
title: Completing the linked open data stack (with or without RDF)

_items.title: 1. An open licence
_items.body: Tell humans and machines they can use your resources, regardless of data format or type etc.

_items.title: 2. A human readable format to maximise re-use
_items.body: Release your resources in a human re-usable format so people can instantly use them, regardless of it they are properly structured, machine readable or linked.

_items.title: 3. A machine readable version
_items.body: Release your data in a a properly structured, machine readable and open format.

_items.title: 4. Use web based identifiers for your resources
_items.body:
If you use identifiers or have a schema, why not make it a web based one by adding http IRIs for resources and column headings, even in a format like CSV!

If you create your own http identifiers these need to resolve and offer and human readable (done in step 2) and machine readable (done in step 3?) version of each resource that has an identifier.

_items.title: 5. Link to others resources
_items.body: Use others schemas, link to other authorities when referring to resources you don’t control e.g. post/zip codes, even in CSV.

body:
For the semantic web to function, computers need access to structured data, the ability to navigate this data and the permission to use it. These principals became the foundation of the linked open data 5-star rating, however these are not sufficient on their own to give the web meaning.

Schemas and vocabularies are critical to add meaning and allow the representation of real world objects in data.

All this has to happen without there being any centralised control, which means that standards have to be flexible to all applications, in all domains and be advantageous in all domains. The Reseource Description Framework (RDF) was proposed as a potential solution which would allow complex knowledge models to be built with a fairly straight forward framework. 

Finally, for machines to be able to make decisions, research from the field of Artificial Intelligence (AI) needs to contribute sets of inference rules that machines can use to conduct automated reasoning.
title: Adding intelligence to the web

body:
In 2001, Sir Tim Berners-Lee put forward a vision for the future of the web; the semantic web. This module explores what the semantic web is, the relation to linked open data, RDF and schemas. 

This module examines:

  • What is the semantic web?
  • Adding intelligence to the web
  • Rules, inference and reasoning
  • The semantic web layer cake
  • Is the semantic web the future of the web?
displayTitle: Is the semantic web the future of the web?
title: Is the semantic web the future of the web?

_items.title: Rules
_items.body:
Rules set out a explicit set of principals and conditions that govern conduct. On the semantic web they set out the conditions that define the world as represented in data. 

This is mainly achieved through the use of schemas. Schemas might define rules which state that in order for two resources to be brothers both must be people and both must be male. The hasBrother relationship can only exist between two people where the brother in question must be male. 

These rules help control inferences on the semantic web.

_items.title: Inference
_items.body:
Inferences are steps in reasoning. On the semantic web inference typically takes the form of deduction where logical conclusions are formed from premises such as:

John hasBrother Paul (Known, True)

According to the schema (rules) hasBrother can only exist between two people and the brother has to be male. Given this it is possible to infer:

John is a Person (Inferred, True)
Paul is a Person (Inferred, True)
Paul is Male (Inferred, True)

However care should be take with open world assumptions:

All apples are fruit (Known, True)
All bananas are fruit (Known, True)
All apples are bananas (Inferred, False)

_items.title: Reasoning
_items.body:
Reasoning is where a number of inferences are put together to establish new facts. 

For example given the following:

Alex-I isBrotherOf Nicholas-I
Nicholas-I isFatherOf Alex-II

We could define a rule which is a compound:

isUncleOf isChainOf isBrotherOf and isFatherOf

Therefor a reasoner could deduce that

Alex-I isUncleOf Alex-II

body:
Data exists in a multitude of structures and formats, as was explored in Choosing the right format for open data. The module introduced the three main structures to data; tabular, hierarchical and network. The problem with these structures is that each is suited to a different format. Given the different combinations of structures and formats, combining and analysing data in these different structures can be problematic. The Resource Description Framework (RDF) proposes a solution to this problem. Any system that can work with one RDF structured format can work with them all, regardless of number of columns in a tabular dataset or the complexity of a network. This module explores:

  • What is the Resource Description Framework (RDF)?
  • Practical uses for RDF
  • How to translate each data structure into RDF
displayTitle: RDF: Three is the magic number
title: RDF: Three is the magic number

body: The Semantic Web Stack (or Layer Cake) is an illustration of the hierarchy of languages, where each layer exploits and uses capabilities of the layers below. It shows how technologies that are standardised for Semantic Web are organised to make the Semantic Web possible. It also demonstrates how the Semantic Web can be built on a base of existing technologies.
title: The Semantic Web Layer Cake

_items.title: 1. Unicode identifiers
_items.body:
The base of stack consists of unicode (internationalised) identifiers or IRIs. These IRIs provide a means to uniquely identify resources on the web. 

IRIs are also a core part of the linked open data 5-star requirement.

_items.title: 2. Syntax (XML)
_items.body:
The next layer proposed a syntax and format for data exchange and representation. In the layer cake this is the eXtensible Markup Language (XML). 

XML is meant to provide a human-readable and machine-readable format for documents. Trying to combine both human and machine readability has received some critisism and preference towards simpler formats, more structured formats such as JSON and YAML.

_items.title: 3. Data interchange, schemas and rules etc
_items.body:
The next layer introduces the standard triple structure (RDF) to represent data, schemas and rules. RDF provides a simple structure that ensures that all machines that understand the triple notion as defined can import and use any data in that structure. 

Of note is the question of why the syntax is lower in the stack than RDF? RDF is a framework that can be represented in many syntax, so picking XML is potentially misleading.

_items.title: 4. Logic, proof and trust
_items.body:
Even with all of the knowledge representation, how do you manage the open and closed world models? How do you know if the data can be trusted or is fake?

This layer of the cake is meant to address those problems and involve further theory from Artificial Intelligence (AI) to help accurately model the world. To this day this layer remains the most under-developed.

body:
Since its definition in 2001, the Semantic Web has seen broad use in academia and specific research institutions however has failed to reach its proposed potential. As early as 2006 a number of the original authors revisited the idea pondering why large-scale adoption and benefit had not been realised. Perhaps the lack of adoption is due to complexity and attempt to make a complete model of the world. 

Maybe the Semantic Web will be similar to Microcosm, an early competitor to the web. Like the Semantic Web, Microcosm was more powerful and versatile than the World Wide Web however this strength was also its weakness. Like the Semantic Web, Microcosm never really had practical solutions to all parts of its stack and by the time they were though about the Web had taken off. 

The whole Semantic Web stack is not yet complete (as of 2017) and while some of the principals like RDF are useful, other parts of the stack, such as XML, have been overtaken with formats such as JSON. It will be interesting to see over the coming decades how the web continues to evolve, perhaps one day we might realise the vision of the Semantic Web, or we might see something else.
displayTitle: Is the Semantic Web the future of the Web?
title: Is the Semantic Web the future of the Web?

body:
In 2001, Sir Tim Berners-Lee put forward a vision for the future of the web; the semantic web. Essentially the semantic web is one where content can not only be displayed by machines for humans to read, but understood, interpreted and used by those machines and agents to intelligently make decisions.

For the semantic web to function, computers need access to structured data, the ability to navigate this data and the permission to use it. These principals became the foundation of the linked open data 5-star rating. Building further, schemas and vocabularies add meaning and allow the definition of rules that can be used to make complex inferences. 

This is a bold vision of the future and as such it is still unrealised in its entirety. Is the Semantic Web the future of the web? There are certainly parts of it that have already seen wide use but the entire stack is not yet complete.

body: As the use of identifiers on the Web evolves, it is good to learn from the experience of others in what and what not to do.
title: Avoiding traps
instruction: Explore the rules below to find out more

_items.title: 1. The lingo
_items.body:
Web based identifiers are more commonly referred to as Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) which are different from Uniform Resource Locators (URLs). 

A URI is an identifier, however a URL is a subset of a URI which also provides a means to locate the resource being identified.

One problem with URLs and URIs is they don't tend to support Chinese characters, thus the notion an IRI (Internationalised Resource Identifier) was introduced to explicitly upgrade URI compatibility.

Lots of lingo to help, but it might end up hindering some.

_items.title: 2. Don't read too much from a URI/IRI
_items.body:
The only thing you can use an identifier for is to refer to an object. When you are not dereferencing, you should not look at the contents of the URI string to gain other information.

- Tim Berners-Lee

This could be a problem for Search Engine Optimisation (SEO) where the readability of the URL helps find the right content. There is however a conflict between URLs that accurately describe things and IRIs which should always resolve, even if they have changed. For example if the identifier for something changes, the old IRI should still resolve, even if it is not accurate any more.

_items.title: 3. Don't include file formats in identifiers
_items.body:
The identifier should not include a file format extension (e.g. ".csv",".json", ".html" etc). The format should be negotiated by the requestor allowing access to lots of different formats (or representations) of the resource dependant on user and usage. 

Format negotiation should either use HTTPs provided Content Negotiation mechanism and/or a query parameter.

For more on these see the REST/APIs module.

_items.title: 4. Don't use underscores in URI/IRIs
_items.body:
Most systems underline links, using underscores "_" in them might get obscured. 

In place a hyphen should be used. 

Some pages on wikipedia fall foul of this problem, e.g. 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_negotiation

_items.title: 5. Use plurals in paths
_items.body:
When defining the path it is a good idea to use a plural (e.g. companies not company). This way if you remove the individual identifier from the URI a user should be able to look up a list of all things at that path (thus a plural). 

Combined with rule 3, it shouldn't make any difference anyway!

body: All different data structures tablular, hierarchical and network can have schemas applied to them. Explore each below and how they apply to a number of different data formats.
title: Schemas in practice

_items.title: Tabular data schemas
_items.body:
A schema for tabular data will define the column titles (keys) and valid values that can be contained in each column. 

In desktop applications like excel, column titles can be simply created through typing them in the top row of the sheet. The problem with this is they can be changed and this is the reason many workbooks use data entry forms to stop the schema being changed. 

The data validation function in excel can enforce rules on what valid values can exist and even allow the selection from a pre-defined list of values. 

A slight issue with excel is that data portability is not very easy as the schema and validations rules cannot be exported from an Excel file and applied to another dataset.

_items.title: XML Schema Definition (XSD)
_items.body:
It is possible to import a schema into Excel, however these have to be defined in the eXtensible Markup Language (XML) format and conform to the XML Schema Definition (XSD) standard.

XML is a hierarchical file format and thus can be challenging to implement for tabular data. 

The example below shows part of the schema definition for the tabular data shown previously. The full schema can be downloaded here. 

Such schema can be used but machines to automatically validate the structure and contents of a datasets. One key advantage of XSD schemas is that they can used with a wide variety tabular and hierarchical data formats. Why not try using the schema from above with an online validation tool against the same data in XML.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

_items.title: JSON Schema
_items.body:
XSD provides a good specification for schema definitions, however XML is challenging to create and use. The JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) schema format provides a much simpler alternative which is easier to create.

Additionally unlike XML, JSON is also natively supported by the Javascript programme language which is used widely on the web. This means it is much more effluent to use and does not require complex parsers to translate from one format to another. 

Shown here is the JSON schema for our tabular data file. Try if for yourself by downloading the tabular data (in CSV) and schema (in JSON) and then using csvlint (a tabular data validator) to validate that the data conforms to the schema. 

Note that XSD is still a far more developed schema definition than JSON schema. As can be seen from this example JSON schema does not have a way to validate the range of inputs currently.

body:
A schema is a blueprint for data that defines a set of integrity constraints and rules relating to the structure and contents of a data resource. A schema will define what the column, titles or keys mean in the data and any valid values or constraints that exist.

In RDF data is not tabular but represented as a triple, for example:

SubjectPredicateObject
http://companies.org
/id/0820202		hasStatusActive

Note that the column titles are subject, predicate and object due to the abstract model of RDF. This means it is not possible to apply schemas to the column headings here. However, as outlined previously the key:value pair related to the value of the predicate, in this case "hasStatus" so this is where the schema applies.
title: Schemas in RDF

body:
In order to define a schema for RDF data, it is necessary to define the constraints of the relationship. The predicate defines the relationship, in this case "hasStatus" which links a "Company" to a potential status "Active, Inactive and Dissolved". 

The schema would therefor be entirely defined against the predicate. To do this the predicate must become an IRI so that it can be used as the subject in a new set of RDF triples that define the constraints of the relationship.
title: Linking the predicate
